  "Allegations" : "CLIENTS PURCHASED A CALLABLE BROKERAGE CD IN APR 2003 FOR 5% INTEREST INCOME. IN MAY 2004 THEY SOLD THE CD AT A LOSS.   "Broker Comment" : "RR SOLD A CALLABLE BROKERAGE CD IN APR 2003 TO CLIENTS FOR 5% INTEREST INCOME, PAYING MONTHLY.  RR CAREFULLY EXPLAINED DIFFERENCES BETWEEN A BANK CD AND A BROKERAGE CD.  RR ADVISED THAT IF CALLED EARLY, THE CD WOULD BE BOUGHT BACK AT PAR.  RR ALSO ADVISED THAT THERE WAS A DEATH PUT ON THE BROKERAGE CD, AND THAT IT WOULD BE BOUGHT BACK AT PAR IF THE OWNER DIED BEFORE THE CD MATURED.  RR ADVISED THAT THE CD COULD NOT BE NOT SOLD BACK EARLY WITHOUT RISK OF LOSS, BUT WOULD NOT LOSE PRINCIPAL IF HELD TO MATURITY.  RR EXPLAINED THAT WHEN CLIENTS RECEIVED QUARTERLY STATEMENTS, THEY WOULD LIKELY SEE A FLUCTUATION OF PRINCIPAL, AGAIN EMPHASIZING THAT IF HELD TO MATURITY, THE CD WOULD NOT LOSE PRINCIPAL.  CLIENTS STATED AT TIME OF PURCHASE THAT THEIR MAIN CONCERN WAS TO RECEIVE A STEADY MONTHLY INCOME FROM THE 5% INTEREST, WHICH THEY RECEIVED REGULARLY UNTIL THEY DECIDED TO SELL BACK THE CD IN MAY 2004.  ALL THE NECESSARY DISCLOSURES WERE SIGNED AND FILED."
